natural problem: A PE class has 12 students, 6 girls and 6 boys. The coach has 4 jerseys in each of 3 colors to mark 3 teams for a soccer tournament. If the coach wants at least one girl and at least one boy on each team, how many ways can he give out the jerseys? (Jerseys of the same color are indistinguishable.)
natural solution: In all, disregarding the gender rule, there are $$\binom{12}4\binom84=\frac{12\cdot11\cdot10\cdot9\cdot8\cdot7\cdot6\cdot5}{4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot4\cdot3\cdot2}=34650$$ways of assigning the teams.

We will count the number of ways a team can have all boys or all girls and subtract from this total. There are 2 choices for the violating gender and 3 choices for the violating color. Once these are picked, there are $\binom64=15$ ways to choose the violating team, and $\binom84=70$ ways to pick the other two teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot15\cdot70=6300$ ways to choose a violating team.

However, this procedure double-counts the assignments that make one team all girls and another all boys. There are 3 choices for the girls team and then 2 choices for the boys team, and $\binom64^2=225$ ways to choose the teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot225=1350$ double-counted arrangements, leaving $6300-1350=4950$ ways to make a team all girls or all boys.
Subtracting this from the total, we get $34650-4950=\boxed{29700}$ ways for the coach to assign the teams.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n_students n_girls n_boys n_colors n_jerseys :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_students = 12"
and h1 : "n_girls = 6"
and h2 : "n_boys = 6"
and h3 : "n_colors = 3"
and h4 : "n_jerseys = 4"
and h5 : "at_least_one_girl_and_boy_on_each_team"
shows  "number_of_ways_to_give_out_jerseys = 29700"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A PE class has 12 students, 6 girls and 6 boys. The coach has 4 jerseys in each of 3 colors to mark 3 teams for a soccer tournament. If the coach wants at least one girl and at least one boy on each team, how many ways can he give out the jerseys? (Jerseys of the same color are indistinguishable.) The final Answer is 29700
 ### Proof
 In all, disregarding the gender rule, there are $$\binom{12}4\binom84=\frac{12\cdot11\cdot10\cdot9\cdot8\cdot7\cdot6\cdot5}{4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot4\cdot3\cdot2}=34650$$ways of assigning the teams.
 We will count the number of ways a team can have all boys or all girls and subtract from this total. There are 2 choices for the violating gender and 3 choices for the violating color. Once these are picked, there are $\binom64=15$ ways to choose the violating team, and $\binom84=70$ ways to pick the other two teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot15\cdot70=6300$ ways to choose a violating team.
 However, this procedure double-counts the assignments that make one team all girls and another all boys. There are 3 choices for the girls team and then 2 choices for the boys team, and $\binom64^2=225$ ways to choose the teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot225=1350$ double-counted arrangements, leaving $6300-1350=4950$ ways to make a team all girls or all boys.
 Subtracting this from the total, we get $34650-4950=\boxed{29700}$ ways for the coach to assign the teams.
 *)

theorem
fixes n_students n_girls n_boys n_colors n_jerseys :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_students = 12"
and h1 : "n_girls = 6"
and h2 : "n_boys = 6"
and h3 : "n_colors = 3"
and h4 : "n_jerseys = 4"
and h5 : "at_least_one_girl_and_boy_on_each_team"
shows  "number_of_ways_to_give_out_jerseys = 29700"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a school, there are 12 students: 6 girls and 6 boys. They are to be divided into 4 teams, each with 3 different colored jerseys. If at least one girl and one boy must be on each team, how many ways can the jerseys be given out? The final answer is 29,700 ways.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes girls boys jerseys_colors :: nat
assumes h0 : "girls = 6"
and h1 : "boys = 6"
and h2 : "jerseys_colors = 3"
and h3 : "\<forall>team. team \<subseteq> {1..12} \<and> card team = 4 \<and> (\<exists>g b. g \<in> {1..girls} \<and> b \<in> {girls+1..boys+girls} \<and> g \<in> team \<and> b \<in> team) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>f. f \<in> {1..3} \<and> color_assigned team f)"
shows  "card {f. \<forall>team. team \<subseteq> {1..12} \<and> card team = 4 \<and> (\<exists>g b. g \<in> {1..girls} \<and> b \<in> {girls+1..boys+girls} \<and> g \<in> team \<and> b \<in> team) \<and> (\<exists>f. f \<in> {1..3} \<and> color_assigned team f)} = 29700"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A PE class has 12 students, 6 girls and 6 boys. The coach has 4 jerseys in each of 3 colors to mark 3 teams for a soccer tournament. If the coach wants at least one girl and at least one boy on each team, how many ways can he give out the jerseys? (Jerseys of the same color are indistinguishable.) The final Answer is 29700
 ### Proof
 In all, disregarding the gender rule, there are $$\binom{12}4\binom84=\frac{12\cdot11\cdot10\cdot9\cdot8\cdot7\cdot6\cdot5}{4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot4\cdot3\cdot2}=34650$$ways of assigning the teams.
 We will count the number of ways a team can have all boys or all girls and subtract from this total. There are 2 choices for the violating gender and 3 choices for the violating color. Once these are picked, there are $\binom64=15$ ways to choose the violating team, and $\binom84=70$ ways to pick the other two teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot15\cdot70=6300$ ways to choose a violating team.
 However, this procedure double-counts the assignments that make one team all girls and another all boys. There are 3 choices for the girls team and then 2 choices for the boys team, and $\binom64^2=225$ ways to choose the teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot225=1350$ double-counted arrangements, leaving $6300-1350=4950$ ways to make a team all girls or all boys.
 Subtracting this from the total, we get $34650-4950=\boxed{29700}$ ways for the coach to assign the teams.
 *)

theorem
fixes girls boys jerseys_colors :: nat
assumes h0 : "girls = 6"
and h1 : "boys = 6"
and h2 : "jerseys_colors = 3"
and h3 : "\<forall>team. team \<subseteq> {1..12} \<and> card team = 4 \<and> (\<exists>g b. g \<in> {1..girls} \<and> b \<in> {girls+1..boys+girls} \<and> g \<in> team \<and> b \<in> team) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>f. f \<in> {1..3} \<and> color_assigned team f)"
shows  "card {f. \<forall>team. team \<subseteq> {1..12} \<and> card team = 4 \<and> (\<exists>g b. g \<in> {1..girls} \<and> b \<in> {girls+1..boys+girls} \<and> g \<in> team \<and> b \<in> team) \<and> (\<exists>f. f \<in> {1..3} \<and> color_assigned team f)} = 29700"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 6 girls and 6 boys in a group, and there are 3 colors of jerseys available. We want to form teams of 4, with at least one girl and one boy on each team. Each team will be assigned a unique jersey color. How many different ways are there to form these teams and assign jersey colors? The final answer is 29,700.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students teams jerseys :: nat
and girls boys :: nat
and distinct_color_teams :: nat

and h3 : "teams = 3"

and h5 : "distinct_color_teams = (nCr 6 2) * (nCr 6 2) * (nCr 6 2)"
shows  "distinct_color_teams = 29700"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_students num_girls num_boys num_colors num_jerseys :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_students = 12"
and h1 : "num_girls = 6"
and h2 : "num_boys = 6"
and h3 : "num_colors = 3"
and h4 : "num_jerseys = 4"
and h5 : "\<forall> color. num_girls + num_boys \<ge> num_jerseys"
and h6 : "\<forall> team. (\<exists> girl boy. girl \<in> team \<and> boy \<in> team)"
shows  "number_of_ways = 29700"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes girls boys jerseys :: nat
assumes h0 : "girls = 6"
and h1 : "boys = 6"
and h2 : "jerseys = 4"
and h3 : "there exists a function f such that f assigns each student to a team in a way that satisfies the coach's requirements"
shows  "card {f} = 29700"
a_6.formal solution:

 *)

theorem
fixes girls boys jerseys :: nat
assumes h0 : "girls = 6"
and h1 : "boys = 6"
and h2 : "jerseys = 4"
and h3 : "there exists a function f such that f assigns each student to a team in a way that satisfies the coach's requirements"
shows  "card {f} = 29700"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A coach has 6 girls and 6 boys on the team and wants to divide them into 4 teams with different jerseys. In how many ways can the coach assign jerseys to the students such that all requirements are satisfied? The final answer is 29,700.

fixes g b j t :: nat

and h1 : "b = 6"

a_7.informal problem: In a sports event, there are 6 girls and 6 boys. Each team must have at least one girl and one boy. If there are 4 jerseys for girls and 3 jerseys for boys, find the number of ways to give out the jerseys to form the teams. The final answer is 29,700.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students girls boys :: nat and jerseys colors :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 12"
and h1 : "girls = 6"
and h2 : "boys = 6"
and h3 : "jerseys = 4"
and h4 : "colors = 3"
and h5 : "\<forall>team. 1 \<le> card {g. g \<in> team \<and> g \<in> {1..girls}} \<and> 1 \<le> card {b. b \<in> team \<and> b \<in> {1+girls..students}}"
shows  "card {teams. \<forall>team \<in> teams. h5 team} = 29700"

Once these are picked, there are $\binom64=15$ ways to choose the violating team, and $\binom84=70$ ways to pick the other two teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot15\cdot70=6300$ ways to choose a violating team.
 However, this procedure double-counts the assignments that make one team all girls and another all boys.  *)

 ### Proof
 In all, disregarding the gender rule, there are $$\binom{12}4\binom84=\frac{12\cdot11\cdot10\cdot9\cdot8\cdot7\cdot6\cdot5}{4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot4\cdot3\cdot2}=34650$$ways of assigning the teams.
 We will count the number of ways a team can have all boys or all girls and subtract from this total. There are 2 choices for the violating gender and 3 choices for the violating color. Once these are picked, there are $\binom64=15$ ways to choose the violating team, and $\binom84=70$ ways to pick the other two teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot15\cdot70=6300$ ways to choose a violating team.
 However, this procedure double-counts the assignments that make one team all girls and another all boys. There are 3 choices for the girls team and then 2 choices for the boys team, and $\binom64^2=225$ ways to choose the teams, for a total of $2\cdot3\cdot225=1350$ double-counted arrangements, leaving $6300-1350=4950$ ways to make a team all girls or all boys.
 Subtracting this from the total, we get $34650-4950=\boxed{29700}$ ways for the coach to assign the teams.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: nat and girls boys jerseys colors :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 12"
and h1 : "girls = 6"
and h2 : "boys = 6"
and h3 : "jerseys = 4"
and h4 : "colors = 3"
and h5 : "at_least_one_girl_and_one_boy_on_each_team"
shows  "number_of_ways_to_give_out_jerseys = 29700"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are 12 students in a class, with 6 girls and 6 boys. There are 4 jerseys and 3 different colors available to give out. If at least one girl and one boy must be on each team, how many ways can the jerseys be given out? The final answer is 29,700.
